questions.text: A 48-year-old construction worker presented with complaints of unilateral loss of sweating on the face. He had a history of trauma to his back 1 month ago. Examination revealed the following findings. What is the likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's or Bernard-Horner's syndrome. It can be caused by the lesion of the white ramus of T1. 

Horner's syndrome is characterized by a constricted pupil (miosis), drooping of the upper eyelid (ptosis), and an absence of sweating of the face (anhidrosis). It occurs due to the disruption of the sympathetic nerve supply.

In the autonomic nervous system, the sympathetic plexus is thoracolumbar and the parasympathetic plexus is craniosacral.

The sympathetic plexus is formed along the side of the spinal cord by white ramus inflow (preganglionic nerve fibers) and gray ramus outflow (postganglionic) and it extends from T1-L2. 

In Horner's syndrome, since the sympathetic inflow is disrupted, the white ramus of the spinal cord is affected as shown below.

The difference between the sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglions are tabulated below.

  Sympathetic ganglions Parasympathetic ganglions
Location Closer to the spinal cord Closer to the organ
Pre-ganglionic fibers Short  Long
Post-ganglionic fibers Long Short

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: Angiography of the upper limb vessels showed blockage in the brachial artery. All of the following vessels will have decreased flow, except:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the anterior circumflex humeral artery will have a normal blood supply. It is a branch of the axillary artery, not the brachial artery.

The brachial artery has 3 branches: 

  • Profunda brachii (accompanies radial nerve in the spiral groove) gives off nutrient artery to the humerus and an ascending branch which anastomoses with posterior circumflex humeral artery. It then divides into: 
    • Anterior descending artery (Radial collateral artery)  
    • Posterior descending artery (Middle collateral artery) 
  • Superior ulnar collateral artery (accompanies ulnar nerve)
  • Inferior ulnar collateral (Supratrochlear) artery

The image given below shows branches of brachial artery.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer was found to have the following finding on his anterior abdominal wall. On examination, you observe that the blood flow in these blood vessels is completely downwards. CT chest showed obstruction of a thoracic vessel. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: Pierces the pericardium at 3rd costal cartilage
Enters the heart at the level of 4th intercostal space
Receives azygous vein below sternal angle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of obstruction of the superior vena cava. It does not pierce the pericardium at the level of 3rd costal cartilage.

The superior vena cava pierces the pericardium opposite 2nd costal cartilage (angle of Louis/sternal angle), at the level of T4-T5 intervertebral disc. It also receives the azygous vein about 2 cm below the sternal plane at the level of T5 vertebra. 

It enters the right atrium at the level of the 4th intercostal space.

Superior vena cava syndrome:

Obstruction of superior vena cava due to metastatic cancers (eg. lung cancer, breast cancer, etc.) can result in reduced venous return from head and neck and upper extremities. It presents with swelling of the neck and face, dyspnea, headache, dizziness, and hemoptysis. Symptoms are aggravated by bending forwards.

On examination, the following may be seen

  • Dilated neck veins
  • Proptosis
  • Papilledema
  • Increased collateral veins on the anterior chest wall - flow is completely downward

CT-chest shows an absence or reduction of the opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.

 

Related Pearl: Angle of Louis

The angle of Loius (sternal angle) is formed by the manubriosternal joint at the level of 2nd costal cartilage anteriorly.

A plane joining the angle of Louis to the intervertebral disc between T4 and T5, called the sternal plane marks the following anatomical landmarks: 

  • Separates superior mediastinum form inferior mediastinum. 
  • Marks the position superior limit of pericardium.
  • Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk
  • Bifurcation of trachea (newer studies shows its lower)  
  • Origin of arch of aorta.
  • Site where superior venacava pierces the pericardium.

questions.text: Which of the following duodenal recesses contains the inferior mesenteric vein in its free margin?
questions.solution:
Paraduodenal recess contains the inferior mesenteric vein in its right free margin.

The fourth part of the duodenum and the duodenojejunal junction has several folds of peritoneum that give rise to many named recesses. They are probably formed during development due to minor aberrations of duodenal rotation and fixation.

The duodenal recesses include:

Left of D4 (sometimes behind)

Opposite L3 vertebra

Behind the duodenomesocolic fold

 Passes in front of ascending branch of left colic artery and inferior mesenteric vein

Slightly left and behind D4

Behind falciform fold of peritoneum 

Right free edge contains inferior mesentric vein and ascending branch of left colic artery

Has a wide orifice, with duodeno-parietal folds on either side

Forms a pocket in the right upper part of mesentery

Has a large, left facing orifice behind a fold raised by the superior mesenteric artery

Between DJ junction and root of transverse mesocolon

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

The anterior relations of the right kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Right lobe of liver
  • Small intestine
Retroperitoneal 
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • 2nd part of duoednum  
  • Hepatic flexure of colon 

The anterior relations of the left kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Stomach
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
 Retroperitoneal
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Pancreas
  • Splenic vessels
  • Splenic flexure and beginning of descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys:

  • One vessel - subcostal vessels
  • Two ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  • Three nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves
  • Four muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transverse abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: A trumpet player presented with hoarseness of voice, cough, and a reducible neck swelling. The neck swelling increases in size on performing the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following regions would you expect to find a defect in?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of laryngocele. The defect is present in the saccule, represented by the area marked A in the above diagram.

The structures marked are: 

B. Ventricle

C. Vestibular ligament

D. Vocal ligament

The saccule is a pouch that ascends forwards from the anterior end of the ventricle, between the vestibular fold and thyroid cartilage.

It is conical in shape and contains around 60 and 70 mucous glands, sited in the submucosa.

It is separated from the thyroid cartilage by the thyroepiglotticus muscle which compresses the saccule. On compression, the secretions of the saccule are released into the vocal cords (which lack mucous glands) to lubricate and protect them from desiccation and infection. 

Clinical significance:

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised trans-glottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined.

External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision through an external neck incision done for external laryngocele.

questions.text: Which of the following does not supply the palate?
questions.solution:
The tonsillar branch of facial artery supplies the palatine tonsil and not the palate.

Blood supply of the palate:

  • Hard palate - greater (descending) palatine artery which is a branch of the third part of the maxillary artery.
  • Soft palate - ascending palatine branch of the facial artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and lesser palatine arteries.

questions.text: The following procedure was planned for a patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. What is not pierced during this procedure?
questions.solution:
A lumbar puncture is planned for this patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. The posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during lumbar puncture.

Structures pierced during lumbar puncture (in that order):

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

questions.text: The medial nucleus of the thalamus predominantly receives input from the ____ and sends output to the _____.
questions.solution:
The medial nucleus of the thalamus predominantly receives input from the hypothalamus and sends output to the prefrontal cortex.

The medial thalamic nuclei contain the large dorsomedial nucleus and several smaller nuclei:

  • Internally, the dorsomedial nucleus is connected to all other thalamic nuclei.
  • Externally, it has 2 major connections—the prefrontal cortex and the hypothalamus. Its functions include integration of somatic, visceral, and olfactory sensory information as well as relation of this sensory information to emotional feelings and subjective states.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
questions.solution:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid bone. 

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle marked as A in the image below.
questions.solution:
The muscle depicted in the diagram is the Pectoralis major, which is a spiral muscle.

questions.text: Fenestrated capillaries are not present in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Fenestrated capillaries are not present in the lungs.

Fenestrated capillaries have gaps between endothelial cells. They are present in certain tissues that allow the passage of larger molecules. Fenestrated capillaries are present in tissues such as

  • Renal glomeruli 
  • Endocrine glands
  • Intestinal mucosa
  • Pancreas.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence of stem cell potency based on their ability to differentiate.
questions.solution:
The correct order of arrangement of stem cells, based on their potency (highest to lowest) to differentiate into different cells is:  Totipotent > Pluripotent > Multipotent  > Oligopotent > Unipotent. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Stem Cells

Types of stem cells

Capacity to differentiate

Examples

Totipotent cells

Can form embryonic and extraembryonic cells

Zygote, early blastomeres

Pluripotent cells

They can form all cell types of an embryonic body but cannot form that of the placenta and umbilical cord

Inner cell mass

Multipotent cells

They form more than one category of cells

Hematopoietic stem cells

Oligopotent cells

They form only one category of cells

Vascular stem cells

Only one type of cell

Liver cell

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows histological section of ureter.

The image shows a thick, fibroelastic, lamina propria lying underneath the stratified, transitional epithelium. There are no mucosal or submucosal glands and no submucosa. There is a layer of smooth muscle outside the mucosa. The outer adventitial layer has fibroelastic connective tissue, with blood vessels, lymphatics and nerves.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought by his mother with complaints of delayed gait development and large head. Examination revealed cystic obstruction of the median outlet of the fourth ventricle causing ballooning of the inferior medullary velum into the cisterna magna. Imperforation of which of the following structures leads to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Blake's pouch cyst is caused due to the nonperforation of the foramen of Magendie.

The roof of the fourth ventricle communicates posteriorly with the cisterna magna through a median aperture called foramen of Magendie. During the fetal development, the roof of IV ventricle is formed by anterior and posterior membranous area (AMA, PMA). Blake's pouch is a temporary finger like growth of the PMA which communicates with the IV ventricle. During the 9th week of the development, the Blake's pouch perforates to form foramen Magendie. Persistence of Blake's pouch leads to a condition called Blake's pouch cyst.

Communications of the ventricular system:

  • Lateral ventricle to the third ventricle: Foramen of Monro
  • III ventricle to IV ventricle: Cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius
  • IV ventricle to subarachnoid space
    • Cisterna magna: Foramen of Magendie (midline)
    • Subarachnoid space: Foramina of Luschka (laterally)

Clinical note:

  • The outflow of CSF from the IV ventricle is via the medial outlet. This is covered by a membrane in the fetus which perforates later. Persistence of this membrane causes cystic obstruction. 
  • In Dandy-Walker malformation, there is presence of many posterior fossa anomalies such as cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle,  hydrocephalus, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis and an enlarged posterior fossa.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant was brought to the pediatric OP for a routine checkup. The child had congenital hypoparathyroidism. CT scan revealed thyroid hypoplasia and absent thymus. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal pouches will most likely cause the given features?
questions.solution:
The defect is most likely to be present in the development of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches as the inferior parathyroid gland and thymus develop from 3rd pouch while the superior parathyroid gland and parafollicular cells of the thyroid develop from 4th pouch.

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches
1
  • Tympanic cavity (middle ear cavity)
  • Auditory tube (eustachian tube) 
2
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Tonsillar fossa
3
  • Inferior parathyroid glands (parathyroid III)
  • Thymus
4
  • Superior parathyroid glands (Parathyroid IV)
  • Ultimobranchial body - gives rise to parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid gland

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures: posterior surface of the navicular, anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations?
questions.solution:
500-600 ml of transient loss/insensible loss per day would have to be accounted for in the calculation.

Although water is lost through sweating especially in hot climates or during physical exertion, we tend to lose water at rest as well. Physiologically, water evaporates from the skin and lungs at a rate of about 600 to 700 ml/day. This is known as insensible water loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle?
questions.solution:
Alpha actinin is the constituent of the marked area.

The image depicts sarcomere and the arrow points towards Z-line. Alpha actinin binds actin to Z-lines.

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.


The thick filaments, which are about twice the diameter of the thin filaments, are made up of myosin; the thin filaments are made up of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.  The thick filaments are lined up to form the A bands, whereas the array of thin filaments extends out of the A band and into the less dense staining I bands.


The lighter H bands in the center of the A bands are the regions where, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.  The Z lines allow for anchoring of the thin filaments. Actinin, titin and desmin are additional structural proteins.


Titin connects Z-lines to the M line and provides the scaffolding to the sarcomere.  Desmin adds structure to Z-lines by connecting Z-line to plasma membrane.


Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second best answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about visceral pain?

choices.text: It is mediated by B fibers

questions.solution:
Visceral pain is poorly localized, unpleasant and associated with nausea and autonomic symptoms. It often originates from thoracic and abdominal cavities, transmitted through small type C pain fibers. 

It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex.

When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is called the dermatomal rule. 

Example: the heart and the arm have the same segmental origin.

Feature

Aδ fiber

C fiber

Stimuli

Mechanical

Thermal

Polymodal

Myelination and tract

Myelinated and carried via Neospinothalamic tract

Unmyelinated and carried via paleospinothalamic tract

Conduction velocity

12–30 m/s

0.5–2 m/s

Impulse conduction

Fast component of pain 

Slow component of pain 

Neurotransmitter

Glutamate

Substance P

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a patient with cyanosis?
questions.solution:
In stagnant hypoxia, blood flow is very low; so, more oxygen is extracted causing an increase in reduced hemoglobin → cyanosis.

Cyanosis - Cyanosis is the dusky bluish discoloration of the tissues occurring when the reduced hemoglobin concentration is more than 5g/dL.

  • Its occurrence depends upon
    • The total amount of hemoglobin in the blood
    • Degree of hemoglobin unsaturation
    • The state of capillary circulation

Option a: In the case of anemia, the total hemoglobin content is low, so enough reduced hemoglobin cannot be formed.

Option b: In histotoxic hypoxia, the amount of reduced hemoglobin formed is very less because the defect is in the tissue O2.

Option c: In CO poisoning, there is the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which is red in color obscure the color of reduced hemoglobin.

questions.text: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying. 

It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, fatty acids, and amino acids.

Primary functions:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Contraction of the gallbladder
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

Other functions:

  • Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juice
  • Inhibition of gastric emptying
  • Trophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon
  • Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing the reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach
  • It promotes satiety

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in strenuous exercise?

choices.text: Right shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve

questions.solution:
Strenuous exercise can cause hyperkalemia by releasing potassium from skeletal muscle.

NOTE: Exercise leads to release of endogenous opiods and is associated with mood enhancement.

questions.text: Hyperosmolarity of renal medulla is due to____
questions.solution:
Hyperosmolarity of the medullary interstitium is mainly due to NaCl and urea.

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are 

  • Active transport of Na+ and co-transport of K+, Cl-, and other ions out of the thick portion of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium.
  • Active transport of ions from the collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Facilitated diffusion of urea from the inner medullary collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Diffusion of only small amounts of water from the medullary tubules into the medullary interstitium

questions.text: Which among the following is not a function of pneumotaxic centre ?

choices.text: Increase in the rate of breathing

questions.solution:
Respiratory rhythm generation is a function of dorsal respiratory group of neurons (and not pneumotaxic center).

Pneumotaxic center:

  • It is located dorsally in the nucleus parabrachialis of the upper pons and it transmits signals to the inspiratory area.
  • Primary effect of this center is to control the switch­off point of the inspiratory ramp, thus controlling the duration of the filing phase of the lung cycle.
  • Function of the pneumotaxic center is primarily to limit inspiration, which has a secondary effect of increasing the rate of breathing, because limitation of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of each respiration.

The pneumotaxic and apneustic centers were proposed by Lumsden, based on sectioning at different levels of the brain stem of cats.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in patients with_____
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is a cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis produced as a result of increased HCO3- loss in feces.

This is because a decrease in HCO3- is replaced by an increase in the concentration of Cl-.  This is a measurable anion and hence the anion gap is normal.

Extra - edge : Siggard-Anderson curve normogram is used to plot the acid-base composition of the blood 

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted mainly on prolactin and growth hormone.

The major hypothalamic releasing hormones are:

  • Thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH)
  • Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH)
  • Growth hormone releasing hormone (GHRH)
  • Gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH)

The major hypothalamic inhibitory hormones are: 

  • Prolactin inhibitory hormone or dopamine
  • Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (GHIH)

questions.text: β HCG is secreted by_____
questions.solution:
The placental gonadotropin in humans is called human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).

  • hCG is a glycoprotein that contains galactose and hexos­amine.
  • It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.
  • it is made up of α and β subunits.
  • hCG-α is identical to the α subunit of LH, FSH, and TSH.
  • hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotropic and has little FSH activity.
  • Its presence in early pregnancy in urine is the basis of the various laboratory tests for pregnancy, and it can sometimes be detected in the urine as early as 14 days after conception.

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

 

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in aboral direction at the rate of 5cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Other options:

Option a - Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option b - Segmentation and mixing helps in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option d - Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below:

questions.text: The cells that will test negative for all mitochondrial markers are______
questions.solution:
The cells that will test negative for all mitochondrial markers are mature red blood cells, as they do not have mitochondria.

Lack of mitochondria is the reason why red blood cells exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate ATP.

questions.text: The main excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS are ______
questions.solution:
Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS. It is responsible for 75% of the excitatory transmission in the brain.

Glycine and GABA are the main inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS. Glycine is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord. GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.solution:
Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine.

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except
questions.solution:
GFR is increased by all of the above except ureteric stone. Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Following ureteral obstruction, there is a progressive fall in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons.

All the other factors/options increase GFR.

questions.text: Urea cycle and Krebs cycle are linked at____.
questions.solution:
Urea cycle and Kreb's cycle are linked at fumarate.

In the urea cycle, cleavage of argininosuccinate to arginine releases the aspartate skeleton as fumarate.

Fumarate in Kreb's cycle, by addition of water, converts to L-malate.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly and a boiled cabbage odour. Investigations were notable for elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is treated by a combination of nitisinone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia and vitamin D resistant rickets.

An odour resembling boiled cabbage resulting from increased methionine metabolites can be noted. Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

Note: A boiled cabbage odour can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids does not undergo transamination?
questions.solution:
Threonine does not undergo transamination.

All amino acids undergo transamination except:

  • Proline
  • Lysine
  • Threonine
  • Hydroxyproline

In transamination, there is a transfer of an amino group from an amino acid to a keto acid to form another pair of amino acid and keto acid, and this reaction is catalyzed by transaminase.

Transaminases are also known as aminotransferases and belong to the class of transferases. They require pyridoxal pyrophosphate or vitamin B6 as their coenzyme. It is important in the biosynthesis of non-essential amino acids.

questions.text: Prostaglandins are derived from _____
questions.solution: Prostaglandins are derived from arachidonic acid through the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway. The prostaglandins (PG) are a group of physiologically active lipid compounds. They are a subclass of eicosanoids and of the prostanoid class of fatty acid derivatives.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical reactions does not occur in mitochondria?
questions.solution:
Fatty acid synthesis does not occur in mitochondria.

Fatty acids are synthesized by an extramitochondrial system, which is responsible for the complete synthesis of palmitate from acetyl-CoA in the cytosol.

The synthesis of fatty acids takes place in the following organs:

  • Liver
  • Kidney
  • Brain
  • Lung
  • Lactating mammary gland
  • Adipose tissue

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peak expiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes has an important role in the pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma in which 5-lipoxygenase enzyme plays an important role.

Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediators such as leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.) which are produced from the breakdown of arachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway. 

The leukotrienes are a family of conjugated trienes formed from eicosanoic acids in leukocytes, mastocytoma cells, platelets, and macrophages by the lipoxygenase (LOX) pathway. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway musculature.

These leukotrienes together with leukotriene B4 also cause increased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes and are involved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

Leukotrienes are also vasoactive, and 5-lipoxygenase is found in arterial walls.

Note: 

Lipoxins are a family of conjugated tetraenes also arising in leukocytes. They are formed by the combined action of more than one lipoxygenase.

questions.text: All of the following vitamins are synthesized by the bacterial flora in the intestine except?
questions.solution:
Niacin is not synthesized by the bacterial flora.

Endogenously synthesized vitamins can be from 2 sources:

1. Synthesized by the body

  • Niacin: synthesized from an amino acid tryptophan
  • Vitamin D: synthesized from 7 Dehydrocholesterol by exposure to UV-B rays (290-315 nm) in the skin.

2. Synthesized in the body (by bacterial flora in the intestine)

  • Vitamin K 
  • Biotin 
  • Pantothenic Acid

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with generalized weakness and lightheadedness for 2 weeks. Blood investigations were notable for decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH. Her peripheral smear showed RBC fragments. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. It is associated with a deficiency of vitamin E.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia.

Note: Vitamin K deficiency does not cause hemolysis. It causes manifestations of impaired coagulation, such as easy bruisability, mucosal bleeding, etc. However, vitamin K toxicity can cause hemolysis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man who presented with burning pain in lower extremities along with staggering gait was diagnosed with burning feet syndrome. On further evaluation, he was found to be deficient in a particular vitamin. The deficient vitamin contains which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that is deficient in burning feet syndrome is vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) which contains beta-alanine.

Beta-alanine is seen in:

  • Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5)
  • Coenzyme A
  • Carnosine
  • Anserine
  • Acyl carrier protein

Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency:

  • GI disturbances
  • Paraesthesia
  • Muscle cramps
  • Ataxia

Burning feet syndrome or nutritional melalgia was first seen in prisoners during the second world war.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Deficiency State

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: The glycosaminoglycan that plays an important role in cellular migration is _________
questions.solution:
Hyaluronic acid plays an important role in cellular migration.

  • Composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetyl glucosamine and glucuronic acid.
  • Serves as a lubricant and shock absorber especially in joints.
  • Plays an important role in permitting cell migration during morphogenesis, wound repair, and tumor cell metastasis.
  • Location: Synovial fluid, vitreous humor, the umbilical cord, cartilage.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose-water, develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
The above clinical features on ingestion of breastmilk suggest a disorder of galactose metabolism.

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Clinical features :

  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver causes liver damage & leads to hepatomegaly, vomiting, convulsions.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate leading to diminished ATP synthesis which affects gluconeogenesis resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves causes intellectual disability.
  • Accumulation of galactitol in the lens causes oil-drop cataract.

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and Mucic acid test is positive.

Treatment is galactose-free diet.

questions.text: The irreversible step of glycolysis involves all of the following enzymes, except ___________.
questions.solution:
Enolase catalyses the conversion of 2 phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, which is a reversible step.

The irreversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate kinase

questions.text: Malate shuttle is important in _______.
questions.solution:
Malate shuttle is important in both, gluconeogenesis and glycolysis.

Malate shuttle is a biochemical system for translocating impermeable electrons (NADH) or substrates (oxaloacetate), in the form of a permeable substance, malate. The semipermeable inner mitochondrial membrane is permeable to malate.

In glycolysis, the impermeable NADH produced in the cytosol (of liver and cardiac cells) are taken up into mitochondria for oxidation via malate shuttle.

In gluconeogenesis, pyruvate in the mitochondria yields impermeable oxaloacetate, which is converted to aspartate and translocated to the cytosol via malate shuttle for the synthesis of glucose.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. Further examination shows generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of muscle biopsy is shown in the given image. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms are hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis.

The treatment for Pompe disease is recombinant enzyme alglucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Northern blotting is used for detection of RNA.
  • Southern blotting is used for detection of DNA.
  • Western blotting is used for detection of protein.

questions.text: What is the percentage of cytosine in DNA if the percentage of thymine residues 28%.
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 22%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species:

Purines = Pyrimidines.

Sum of Purine =Sum of Pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 28%, therefore adenine is also 28%. Hence adenine+thymine = 56% and Guanine + cytosine = 44%. 

No of Guanine=No of Cytosine, so the percentage of cytosine = 44/2 = 22%.

questions.text: A mutation in which section of DNA could influence the binding of RNA polymerase to the DNA?
questions.solution:
A mutation in the Promoter section of DNA could influence the binding of RNA polymerase to the DNA.

The regulatory portion of the operon is upstream of the three structural genes, and consists of the following:

  • The promoter (P) region where RNA polymerase binds
  • Two additional sites, the operator (O) site, and the CAP site, where regulatory proteins bind

Note: A lack of Corepressor would result in the inability of the cell to ʺturn offʺ genes.

Corepressor is a substance that inhibits the expression of genes. In prokaryotes, corepressors are small molecules whereas, in eukaryotes, corepressors are proteins.

A corepressor binds to the repressors and activates the repressor transcription factor, and the repressor, in turn, binds to the operator site, thereby blocking the transcription from the structural genes.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

questions.text: What is the most common cause of cell injury?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia is the most common cause of cell injury.

Causes of cell injury include:

  • Hypoxia
  • Physical agents
  • Chemical agents and drugs
  • Infectious agents
  • Immunologic reactions
  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Nutritional imbalances

The mechanism of hypoxic cell injury is reduced oxidative respiration. The most common cause of hypoxia is ischemia.

Hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) is a transcription factor with protective effects against hypoxic injury such as:

  • Promotion of blood vessel formation
  • Stimulation of cell-survival pathways
  • Enhancement of anaerobic glycolysis

The cells most sensitive to hypoxia are neurons. The most sensitive neurons include:

  • Pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus (especially, area CA1, also known as Sommer’s sector)
  • Cerebellar Purkinje cells
  • Pyramidal neurons in the cerebral cortex

The cells most resistant to hypoxia are fibroblasts.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was brought to the ER by his friends after they found him lying unconscious next to an empty antifreeze bottle. Investigations were significant for the following findings. This condition predominantly affects which part of the kidney?

BUN - 60mg/dl

S. creatinine - 3.2mg/dl

S. potassium - 7mmol/L

ABG - high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Urine analysis - calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ingestion of ethylene glycol. Toxins usually result in ATN by causing damage to the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs).

Ethylene glycol poisoning produces marked ballooning and hydropic or vacuolar degeneration of PCT. Calcium oxalate crystals are often also found in tubular lumens.

Direct toxic injury to the tubules in ATI can be caused by:

  • Endogenous agents: Myoglobin, hemoglobin, monoclonal light chains, bile/bilirubin
  • Exogenous agents:  Drugs, radiocontrast dyes, heavy metals, and organic solvents

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of joint pain and progressive loss of joint motion. On examination, symmetric joint swelling of the hands is seen. A subcutaneous nodule is seen over her right forearm. Microscopy of the excised nodule shows the findings given in the image below. Which of the following lab findings will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Uric acid crystals in joint aspirate
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals in joint aspirate

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing necrotizing granuloma in the subcutaneous nodule is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's serum will test positive for rheumatoid factor. 

Microscopy of the excised nodule shows a necrotizing granuloma with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by a prominent rim of activated macrophages and numerous lymphocytes and plasma cells.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that principally attacks the joints, producing nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory synovitis. The inflammation progresses to the destruction of the articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints.

80% of patients have serum IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc portions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies are called rheumatoid factor. Another antibody that is specific for RA is anti-citrullinated peptides (CCPs). 

The characteristic histologic features of RA include: 

  • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation
  • Dense inflammatory infiltrates
  • Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis
  • Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces
  • Osteoclastic activity in the underlying bone    

This all together leads to a mass of edematous synovium called pannus, which grows over the articular cartilage and causes its erosion.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is more common in women with low parity
The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations

questions.solution:
The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most commonly bilateral.

The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary. 

Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors. 

There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian tumors is CA-125.

questions.text: A young male presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The small bowel is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the small bowel infarction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

PAN affects small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically affects young adults. The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement (most common) or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by involvement of gastrointestinal vessels.

30% of patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B and deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes in the affected vessels.

Specific complaints related to a particular organ system may also dominate the clinical picture:

  • Renal - renal failure, hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal - arthritis, arthralgia, myalgia
  • Peripheral nervous system - Peripheral neuropathy, mononeuritis multiplex
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Abdominal pain, bleeding, bowel infarction and perforation
  • Skin - rash, purpura, cutaneous infarcts, livedo reticularis, Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Cardiac - Congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, pericarditis
  • Genitourinary - Testicular, ovarian or epididymal pain
  • Central nervous system - Cerebral vascular accident, seizure, altered mental status
    Death usually results from gastrointestinal complications, particularly bowel infarcts and perforation, and cardiovascular causes.

Diagnosis - The diagnosis is based on the demonstration of characteristic findings of vasculitis on biopsy material. An elevated ESR is almost always present. All patients should be screened for hepatitis B and C. 

Treatment - Prednisolone and cyclophosphamide have shown favorable results. In patients with hepatitis B, antiviral therapy is used in combination with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange.

Option A: Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. 

Option B: Cystic medial degeneration leads to dissecting aortic aneurysm.

Option C: Mönckeberg’s arteriosclerosis does not cause infarction.

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except _____.
questions.solution:
Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens.

  • Exogenous pyrogens include lipopolysaccharides (LPS) of bacterial walls
  • Endogenous pyrogens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins

Fever, characterized by an elevation of body temperature, usually by 1° to 4°C, is one of the most prominent manifestations of the acute-phase response, especially when inflammation is associated with infection.

 Bacterial products, such as LPS (called exogenous pyrogens), stimulate leukocytes to release cytokines such as IL-1 and TNF (called endogenous pyrogens) that increase the enzymes (cyclooxygenases) that convert arachidonic acid (AA) into prostaglandins.

Prostaglandins that are produced in the vascular and perivascular cells of the hypothalamus. In the hypothalamus, the prostaglandins, especially PGE2, stimulate the production of neurotransmitters that reset the temperature set point at a higher level.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented to the ER with severe bleeding following a road traffic accident. He was found to be a known cardiac disease patient and is on anticoagulant therapy.  As an intern, you were asked to collect blood for coagulation studies. Which color vacutainer will you pick?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.

Other anticoagulants, including oxalate (grey), heparin (green), and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA)(lavender) are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V and VIII) are unstable in oxalate, whereas heparin and EDTA directly inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. 

Additional benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate, and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin.

Image shows color coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses:

Note:

Heparin is used for blood sample collection for electrolyte estimation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with acute onset of testicular pain. On examination, the left testis is enlarged and tender. Orchidectomy shows intense congestion, widespread hemorrhage, and areas of infarction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion.

Adult torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain.

It results from a bilateral anatomic defect that leads to increased mobility of the testes (bell­clapper abnormality). Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction.

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.

If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable.

Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth; the cause is unknown.

questions.text: Screening mammograms of a 45-year-old lady showed clusters of microcalcification following which needle biopsy was done. The microscopic image is as given below. IHC marker that can be used to rule out invasive foci _________
questions.solution:
The given image is of comedo type ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma.

DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the intact basement membrane. Once the tumour cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within stroma, they are considered to be invasive carcinoma.

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography.

Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts/lobules in DCIS. Hence the myoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCIS whereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma.

However, myoepithelial markers may be diminished in high grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts/lobules.

Note: Carcinoma in situ was originally classified as DCIS or lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) based on their resemblance to normal ducts or lobules. It is now recognized that these growth patterns are not related to the cell of origin, but rather reflect differences in tumor cell genetics and biology.

questions.text: In the following osmotic fragility curve, ‘A’ occurs in _________.
questions.solution:
In the given osmotic fragility curve, the green-shaded region is the normal zone of red blood cell hemolysis. Here, curve A is more towards the left, indicating that RBCs have an increased osmotic fragility. When there is an increase in osmotic fragility, hemolysis occurs at a higher concentration of NaCl. Curve A signifies a higher concentration of NaCl in this graph which occurs in hereditary spherocytosis.

In thalassemia and sickle-cell anemia, on the other hand, the red cells become more resistant to osmotic lysis due to which there is a decrease in osmotic fragility. Hence, the curve will shift to the right.

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents to the opd with complaints of cough, hemoptysis, dyspnoea and weight loss. Bronchoscopy suggested lung carcinoma.  Lung biopsy revealed the following picture. Which of the following carcinomas is the clinical scenario suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adenocarcinoma lung.

It is the most common form of lung cancer.

It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumor cells.

It is usually located peripherally (it arises from terminal bronchiole).

Histologically lepidic growth patterns are seen in adenocarcinomas. It refers to the pattern of spread of the tumor in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resemble butterflies resting on a fence.

Tumors 3 cm or less in diameter characterized by lepidic growth pattern without stromal invasion are now called adenocarcinoma in situ (formerly called bronchoalveolar carcinoma).

questions.text: A lesion in the vertebra is composed of multiple, blood-filled cystic spaces separated by septae composed of plump uniform fibroblasts, multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells, and reactive woven bone. The bone is lined by osteoblasts. There is no cartilage or necrosis. The lesion is most likely to be a ________.
questions.solution:
• The histopathological description of the lesion matches that of an aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a tumor characterized by multiloculated blood-filled cystic spaces.
  • It affects all age groups, but generally occurs during the first 2 decades of life and has no sex predilection.
  • Site: Metaphysis of long bones and the posterior elements of vertebral bodies.
  • The majority of secondary ABC arise in association with benign neoplasms, most commonly giant-cell tumor (GCT) of the bone, chondroblastoma, osteoblastoma, and fibrous dysplasia, and less frequently, osteosarcoma.
  • Radiographically, ABC is usually an eccentric, expansile, lesion with well-defined margins
  • Most lesions are completely lytic and often contain a thin shell of reactive bone at the periphery.
  • The spindle cells of ABC frequently demonstrate rearrangements of chromosome 17p13, leading to USP6 overexpression.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis ?
questions.solution:
Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Sporangiospore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.

Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:

Class Sexual spore Asexual spore
Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospores Sporangiospores
Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia
Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia
Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes) Yet to be identified Conidia

Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.

Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: A microbiologist performs the following test and observes swelling of the capsule. In which of the following organisms will this phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Quellung reaction and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it. 

In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen.

Mnemonic for capsulated organisms:

Some- Streptococcus pneumoniae

Killers- Klebsiella pneumoniae

Have- Haemophilus influenzae

Nice- Neisseria meningitidis

Capsules- Cryptococcus neoformans

F1 Protein Capsule  Yersinia pestis

questions.text: A destitute patient brought to the casualty is found to have the following organism on his body. Which of the following diseases is not spread by this organism?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a human body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis. Rocky Mountain spotted fever is not spread by lice.

Tick (Dermacentor andersoni) is the vector of Rocky Mountain spotted fever and the causative organism is Rickettsia rickettsii.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pattern recognition receptor?
questions.solution:
BMP-like receptor is not a pattern-recognition receptor. Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are multifunctional proteins regulating cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. There are no BMP-like receptors. 

Pattern-recognition receptors (PRRs) play a key role in the innate immune response. They recognize pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), which are common to whole classes of microbes, and initiate an immune response. 

PRRs are classified as follows:

  • Membrane-bound PRRs: 
    • Toll-like receptors (TLR)- detect microbial carbohydrates and lipoproteins
    • C-type lectin receptors (CLR)- detect mannose residues
  • Cytoplasmic (intracellular) PRRs:
    • Nucleotide oligomerization (NOD)-like receptors (NLR) - NOD1 and NOD2 - Detects bacterial cell wall peptidoglycans 
    • RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs) - Detects viral RNA 
  • Secreted PRRs

questions.text: All of the following are constituents of MacConkey agar except?
questions.solution:
Cysteine is not a constituent of MacConkey agar

Contents of MacConkey agar: Mnemonic: PLANT

P – Peptone 

L – Lactose                 

A – Agar

N – Neutral red

T– Sodium Taurocholate

MacConkey agar showing LF and NLF

questions.text: Spring catarrh is _____ hypersensitivity reaction.
questions.solution:
Spring catarrh is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

Spring Catarrh (Vernal Conjunctivitis) is a bilateral, seasonally recurrent, chronic conjunctivitis due to type I hypersensitivity allergic reaction to an external antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most commonly implicated in infective endocarditis in prosthetic valves?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common organism implicated in prosthetic valve endocarditis.

questions.text: A microbiologist is working with PCR and wishes to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. Which of the following types of PCR should he do?
questions.solution:
Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. 

Types of PCR:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Real-time PCR: This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
  • Multiplex PCR: Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity.

questions.text: A patients plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to _____ ?
questions.solution:
Interferon beta is secreted during infection due to viruses. It is produced by fibroblasts. 

Types of interferons: 

  • Alpha Interferon (Leukocyte interferon) is produced by leucocytes. It has antiviral activity. 
  • Beta Interferon (Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It has antiviral activity. 
  • Gamma Interferon (Immune interferon) is produced by T-lymphocytes. It is concerned with immuno-modulatory and anti-proliferative functions.

questions.text: All of the following are used as a scolicidal agent in PAIR except ____
questions.solution:
Hypotonic saline is not used as a scolicidal agent in PAIR.

PAIR – Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, and Re-aspiration is the treatment of choice in the early stages of hydatid disease

In this technique the steps involved are:

  • USG or CT guided puncture of the cyst
  • Aspiration of the cyst fluid
  • Injection of scolicidal agent
  • Re-aspiration of fluid after 5 minutes

The following agents can be used as scolicidal agents.

   

Cetrimide

  

95% Alcohol

  

Hypertonic saline

  

Sodium hypochlorite

  

Hydrogen peroxide

questions.text: Which of the following is  a marker of active replication of hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
HBeAg, HBV DNA, and HBV DNA polymerase are markers of active viral replication.

HBeAg is a qualitative marker while HBV DNA is a quantitative marker of the replicative phase.

questions.text: Culture media for leptospira is :
questions.solution: Ellinghausen, McCullough,Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used for leptospira.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug is effective only in absence seizures?
questions.solution:
Ethosuximide is effective and indicated only in absence seizures.

Sodium valproate is a wide spectrum antiepileptic indicated in almost all types of epilepsy. It is considered as first line therapy for absence seizures in cases assocaited with secondary GTCS. It is the drug of choice for all types of seizures except for partial seizures and infantile spasms.

questions.text: Dipivefrine is a prodrug of
questions.solution:
Dipivefrine is a prodrug of adrenaline (epinephrine).

Adrenaline has poor corneal penetration. Dipivefrine penetrates cornea and is converted into adrenaline by the esterases.

questions.text: All of the following statements about theophylline are correct except _____

choices.text: Increase in dose is required in cardiopulmonary disease
Decreases the breakdown of cAMP in smooth muscles
Increase in dose is required in smokers
It is a non-selective phosphodiesterase inhibitor

questions.solution:
A decrease in dose (not an increase in the dose) of theophylline is required in cardiopulmonary disease. This is because reduced clearance of theophylline is seen in liver disease, pneumonia, and heart failure. (option a)

In smokers, clearance of theophylline is increased due to the induction of CYP1A2 enzyme. (option c)

Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor that decreases the breakdown of cAMP levels in smooth muscles resulting in bronchodilation. (option b and d)

questions.text: All of the following statements about clopidogrel are correct except ______

choices.text: The onset of action is slow
It has a long duration of action
It is activated by the hepatic CYP2C19

questions.solution:
Clopidogrel acts by irreversible inhibition of P2Y12 receptors of the platelets.

The onset of action is slow as it requires metabolic activation by the hepatic CYP2C19 enzyme. Antiplatelet action starts by 4 hours and develops over days (Options B and D).

Due to irreversible inhibition of platelet P2Y12 receptors the duration of action is long and lasts for 5-7 days (Option C).

questions.text: Male gynecomastia is seen with_____
questions.solution: Spironolactone results in male gynecomastia by decreasing testosterone production, increasing peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol, and displacing estradiol from their plasma-protein-binding sites.

questions.text: A patient developed abnormal posturing and grimacing following the administration of metoclopramide. Which drug will you administer to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of dystonia associated with D2 blocker (metoclopramide) use. Promethazine is the drug of choice.

It is a first-generation antihistaminic having significant central anticholinergic activity.

questions.text: While discharging a patient with Parkinson's disease, the treating physician writes a prescription of levodopa along with another drug that can increase the bioavailability of the former. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Entacapone is a peripheral COMT inhibitor that increases the bioavailability of levodopa.

It inhibits the peripheral metabolism of levodopa thereby increasing the bioavailability of levodopa.  

Options B and D: Ropinirole and apomorphine are dopamine receptor agonists and do not have any significant effect on levodopa bioavailability.

Option C: Amantadine which is an antiviral drug is also anti-Parkinsonian due to its varied actions including increased release and decreased uptake of dopamine. It has no significant effect on the bioavailability of levodopa.

questions.text: A patient having both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia was prescribed an atypical antipsychotic with partial D2 agonism. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic showing D2 partial agonism. It has a higher affinity for D2 receptors than for 5HT2A receptors.

As a partial agonist, aripiprazole has a dual-action which makes it useful in patients with both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Options A & D: Clozapine and risperidone are atypical antipsychotics with predominant 5HT2A antagonistic activity over D2 antagonism. 

Option B: Fluphenazine is a typical antipsychotic. They have predominant D2 antagonism property and such action on the mesocortical pathway may increase the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Related Pearl: Actions of antipsychotic drugs

Dopaminergic pathway Significance Action of drug blocking D2 receptors
Nigrostriatal Movement Extrapyramidal symptoms
Mesolimbic Speech, grasp of reality, mentation, and mood Reduces positive symptoms of schizophrenia
Mesocortical Motivation, pleasure, socialization May increase negative symptoms of schizophrenia
Tuberoinfundibular pathway Inhibits prolactin release Hyperprolactinemia
Chemoreceptor trigger zone Vomiting reflex Anti emetic

questions.text: Which of the following statements about methotrexate is false?

choices.text: Non-proliferative cells are resistant to it
It targets the S-phase of the cell cycle

questions.solution:
Folinic acid, also known as leucovorin, the active form of folic acid, is administered with methotrexate to reduce the toxicity associated with higher doses. It does not enhance the action of methotrexate.

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. It is a cell cycle (S-phase) specific antineoplastic agent and non-proliferative cells are relatively resistant to it. 

Bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal mucosa inflammation (mucositis) are the common side effects seen due to inhibition of DNA synthesis. 

Methotrexate toxicity:

  • Prevention - administration of leucovorin/folinic acid.
  • Treatment - maintaining adequate hydration and forced alkaline diuresis in patients with normal renal function.
  • Glucarpidase is an intravenous drug administered in patients who have impaired renal function.

questions.text: What does time for peak plasma concentration (Tmax) indicate?
questions.solution:
The time for peak plasma concentration (Tmax) indicates the rate at which the drug is absorbed from the administered site. It depends on both the administered site and the drug formulation.

This is used to determine the timing of the administration of hypnotics with respect to sleep timings. A hypnotic with a higher rate of absorption might be preferred to induce sleep at a shorter latency as the target concentration can be achieved earlier.

questions.text: You are asked to prescribe a cholinergic agent to a patient suffering from Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following drugs cannot be chosen?
questions.solution:
Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist indicated for the management of moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease.

Donepezil, galantamine, and tacrine are centrally acting cholinesterase inhibitors indicated for Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about heparin?

choices.text: It is the weakest acid found in the body
It is commonly obtained from pig intestine
It acts by activation of antithrombin

questions.solution:
Heparin is the strongest organic acid present in the body.

Option B: Most commercial preparations of heparin are extracted from the porcine intestinal mucosa.

Option C: Heparin acts indirectly through the activation of antithrombin and inhibition of factors IIa and Xa.

Option D: Heparin use can result in thrombocytopenia due to the development of antibodies to heparin-platelet factor 4 complex.

questions.text: A patient with a glioblastoma multiforme is started on mannitol as palliative therapy. Which of the following statements is false regarding its diuretic action?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. These drugs do not cause much change in the GFR.

Osmotic diuretics cause extraction of fluid from the intracellular compartment resulting in the expansion of the extracellular compartment. The renal blood flow increases and renin release is inhibited. An increase in renal medullary blood flow removes NaCl and urea from the renal medulla thus reducing medullary tonicity. There is not much change in the total GFR.

questions.text: A patient was referred by a doctor to a radiologist for a CT scan and the doctor was given money for the referral. What is this unethical act called?
questions.solution:
This unethical act of receiving a commission for referring a patient is referred to as Dichotomy. 

Dichotomy is an unethical act wherein a doctor receives a gift, commission or money for referring, recommending, or procuring a patient for any medical, surgical or other treatments. Fee splitting is unethical in India.

questions.text: According to Indian Evidence Act (IEA), section 45 gives information regarding _______
questions.solution:
IEA Section 45 gives information regarding Expert witness. Similarly, IEA Section 154 gives information regarding Hostile witness.

The important Sections under IEA (Indian evidence act) include :
