questions.text: Dental numbering is done using:
questions.solution:
Palmer’s notation is used for charting of teeth. Teeth will be numbered from 1 to 8 starting from central incisor till the third molar in each quadrant. 

.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change:
questions.solution:
The image shows suggillation.

Lividity of death: Postmortem lividity (suggilation, postmortem hypostasis/postmortem staining/livor mortis/suggillation/vibices) develops in the dependent portions of the body due to engorged vessels showing through the skin.

questions.text: In a case of suspected homicide, the wife has been arrested for allegedly shooting the husband. She was found to be guilty based on the presence of gunpowder residue on her hands. Which of the following tests is the most sensitive for detection of gunpowder residue?

choices.text: Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy
Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis

questions.solution:
Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis is the most sensitive test for detection of gunshot residue(GSRs).

Tests for detection of gunpowder residue

  • Dermal nitrate (paraffin) test
  • Harrison and Gilroy test
  • Neutron Activation Analysis (NAA)
  • Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (FAAS)
  • Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) - a variant of Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy
  • Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis (SEM -EDX)

The most commonly used method for detection of gunshot residue is scanning electron microscopy–energy-dispersive x-ray spectrometry (SEM–EDX).

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a false positive hydrostatic test in fetus seen?
questions.solution:
The hydrostatic test is falsely positive in the case of putrefied fetus.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth. If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is stillborn.

An unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float, giving a false positive test, due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction. 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the doctor because his family found him dressed as a woman. He says that he derives sexual pleasure from this act. However, he has no wish to undergo sex-change surgery. What is this type of perversion called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetishistic transvestism.

It is a paraphilia characterized by recurrent sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges, or behavior involving the wearing of clothes of the opposite sex and appearing as a member of the opposite sex. It is also called transvestic fetishism. It is usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes.

Fetishistic transvestism is a paraphilia whereas transvestism is a gender identity disorder. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality in fetishistic transvestism.

Option A: Transsexualism refers to an obsessional desire to become a member of the opposite sex and seek surgery for anatomical alterations. 

Option C: Frotteurism refers to a person who obtains sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, or thighs, in public places). It is punishable under Section 290 IPC, with fine up to 200 Rs.

Option D: Gender dysphoria is a term that describes a sense of unease that a person has due to a mismatch between their biological sex and their gender identity. This sense of unease or dissatisfaction can lead to depression and anxiety and can have a harmful impact on daily life.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13
years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person

questions.text: A drug dealer was arrested and strips of dried blotting paper printed with colorful graphics were confiscated from him. Which of the following substances is commonly sold like that?
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is most commonly sold as small squares of dried blotter paper printed with colorful graphics.

It is a colorless, tasteless, odorless, water-soluble substance. A heavy user of LSD is called an acid head.

questions.text: A 30-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance. It is seen in poisoning with boric acid.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a beefy red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum, is seen. The intense erythema is followed by extensive exfoliation.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

questions.text: Dimercaprol is indicated as an antidote in patients with which of the following poisoning?
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol (BAL) is an antidote for gold, arsenic (except arsine), or acute mercury poisoning (except non-alkyl mercury). It is also an adjunct to edetate calcium disodium in acute lead poisoning.

Dimercaprol has also been approved by the FDA to treat Wilson's disease but not acute copper poisoning. The use of dimercaprol in the management of poisoning for other heavy metals has not been validated.

Note: Mnemonic: B.A.L. for M.A.L. (Mercury, arsenic, and lead).

questions.text: Using impedance audiometry, stapedial reflexes are being assessed in a child with cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following cranial nerves is being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 7th and 8th cranial nerves are being tested in a child by assessing the stapedial reflexes. 

The afferent of stapedial reflex is the 8th cranial nerve and efferent is the 7th cranial nerve.

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both tympanic membranes exhibits a reddish blush, known as Schwartz sign, due to increased vascularity. This finding, combined with a history of bilateral conductive hearing loss, is indicative of active otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

On examination, Schwartz sign/flamingo flush showing a red blush of the tympanic membrane can be seen. This appearance is due to hypervascularization in the region of the cochlear promontory, which occurs in the active phase of otosclerosis as new blood vessels form around the focus of bone remodelling.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to speed up the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Hearing aids are used in patients who refuse or are unfit for the surgery.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Option A: A rising sun sign is seen in the glomus tumour.

Option C: The setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: What would be the primary aim of surgery in a patient presenting with the following otoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a white mass located in the anterosuperior quadrant behind the intact eardrum suggestive of cholesteatoma. The primary aim is to clear the disease and render the ear safe. The second priority is to preserve or reconstruct the hearing, but never at the cost of the primary aim.

The primary goal of surgery in cholesteatoma cases is to clear the disease completely, eliminating the mass and preventing further complications.
Cholesteatoma can erode bone and cause damage to structures in the middle ear, making clearance crucial for patient safety.

Secondary Priorities:

  • Hearing Restoration: While preserving or reconstructing hearing is important, it is considered a secondary priority to clearing the disease.
  • Perforation Closure: Closing the perforation is also important but is not the primary aim; it is often addressed after clearing the disease.

Other Options:

  • While hearing restoration is a secondary goal, it should not compromise the primary aim of clearing the disease.
  • Reconstruction is a part of the overall surgical approach, especially if there is damage, but it serves the broader goal of disease clearance.
  • Closing the perforation is important, but it is secondary to the primary aim of disease clearance in cholesteatoma cases.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
questions.solution:
In acute maxillary sinusitis, antral lavage is actually contraindicated for the risk of osteomyelitis.

Antral lavage is usually done therapeutically to remove pus and diagnostically for confirmation of chronic maxillary sinusitis. It can also be done to collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Blood-tinged nasal discharge is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma.

Other early features include:

  • Nasal stuffiness
  • Facial paraesthesias 
  • Pain
  • Epiphora.

These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis.

Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymph nodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged.

Option C: Proptosis is a late feature that occurs after the invasion of the orbit. 

Option D: Dental pain is a late feature that occurs due to expansion of the alveolus after the tumor spreads inferiorly.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has been posted for an adenoidectomy procedure. Which of the following conditions if present in this child will be a contraindication to performing the surgery?
questions.solution:
Cleft palate is a contraindication to perform adenoidectomy as removal of adenoids causes velopharyngeal insufficiency. 

Velopharyngeal insufficiency is a condition where the soft palate does not close tightly against the back of the throat. This leads to air coming out the nose (characterized by hypernasality) during speech. 

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft palate or submucous palate. 
  • Hemorrhagic diathesis.
  • Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: Which of the following cases cannot be posted for an elective tonsillectomy?

choices.text: A young adult with chronic tonsillitis refractory to treatment
A patient with unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspected malignancy
A middle-aged man with recurrent quinsy

questions.solution:
Acute tonsillitis is a contraindication for tonsillectomy and hence, cannot be posted for elective surgery.

Acute tonsillitis or any upper respiratory tract infection is a contraindication for tonsillectomy since there is an increased chance of hemorrhage and sepsis.

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
    Seven or more episodes in 1 year, or
    Five episodes per year for 2 years, or
    Three episodes per year for 3 years, or
    Two weeks or more of lost school or work in 1 year
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of  severe laryngomalacia include:

  • Difficulty feeding
  • Increased effort in breathing
  • Poor weight gain 
  • Pauses in the breathing 
  • Frequent spitting up

questions.text: Pain is most severe in which stage of ASOM?
questions.solution:
Pain is most severe in stage of suppuration.

questions.text: Vasodilator of the inner ear is _____.
questions.solution:
Betahistine is a vasodilator of the inner ear. It is used in the treatment of Meniere's disease.

It is reported to act by:

  • Improving microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea.
  • Inhibiting vestibular nuclei activity.

Note: The answer has been revised to betahistine from nicotinic acid, to reflect new updates in the reference.

questions.text: 6 year old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Management includes
questions.solution: Swelling in the nose indicates possibility of septal haematoma which mainly presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and needs immediate surgical drainage.

questions.text: In the given image, the artery of epistaxis is indicated by _____.
questions.solution:
Structure marked C is the sphenopalatine artery which is called the “artery of epistaxis”.

It is called the artery of epistaxis since the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is by the sphenopalatine artery and it is the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

  • A: Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • B: Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • D: Greater palatine artery

questions.text: CSF rhinorrhea is seen in all except_______
questions.solution:
CSF rhinorrhea is seen in naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture, Le-Fort II & III but not in Le-Fort I which is transverse fracture of maxilla.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in oropharynx?
questions.solution:
Lingual tonsils are lymphoid tissue seen in the base of tongue. Hence its part of the oropharynx.

Oropharynx includes Base of tongue, Palatine tonsils, Anterior & Posterior pillars, Vallecula and Posterior pharyngeal wall.

Pharyngeal end of pharyngotympanic tube and Fossa of Rosenmuller are present in lateral wall of nasopharynx.

Pyriform fossa is a part of hypopharynx.

questions.text: In laryngeal cancer, hoarseness of voice results from______
questions.solution:
• Hoarseness in glottis Ca is early because lesions of cord affect its vibratory capacity. 
  • Hoarseness in supraglottic and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to:
    • Vocal cords with infiltration of thyroarytenoid muscle or
    • Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve or
    • Cricoarytenoid joint involvement.
  • Though this is a late feature, it is usually present at first presentation since patients usually come late.

questions.text: Roper-Hall system is used for the grading of ________.
questions.solution:
Roper–Hall system is used for the classification of chemical injuries to the eye.

Chemical injuries to the eye:

  • Alkali burns are twice as common as acid burns.
  • Alkalis tend to penetrate more deeply than acids, as the latter coagulate surface proteins, forming a protective barrier.
  • Most commonly involved alkalis are ammonia, sodium hydroxide, and lime.
  • Grading of severity (Roper–Hall system)
    • On the basis of corneal clarity and severity of limbal ischemia
      • Grade 1  is characterized by a clear cornea (epithelial damage only) and no limbal ischemia (excellent prognosis).
      • Grade 2 shows a hazy cornea but with visible iris detail and less than one-third of the limbus being ischemic (good prognosis).
      • Grade 3 manifests as a total loss of the corneal epithelium, stromal haze obscuring iris detail, and between one-third and half of the limbus showing ischemia (guarded prognosis).
      • Grade 4 manifests with an opaque cornea and more than 50% of the limbus showing ischemia (poor prognosis).

questions.text: The following fundus image shows ______.
questions.solution:
The image shows Drusens, which is a feature of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (AMD). 

Drusens are the earliest visible clinical signs of AMD. They are composed of lipid, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

There are two types of ARMD.

  • Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) AMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD.
  • Wet (exudative, neovascular) AMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.

Clinical classification 

Category

Definition

(based on the presence of lesions within two disc diameters of the fovea in either eye)
No apparent
age-related changes		 No drusen
No AMD pigmentary abnormalities
Normal age-related
changes		 Only drupelets 
No AMD pigmentary abnormalities
Early AMD Medium Drusen (>63 μm but
<125 μm)
No AMD pigmentary abnormalities
Intermediate AMD Large Drusen (>125 μm)
Any AMD pigmentary
abnormalities
Late AMD Neovascular AMD and/or
any geographic atrophy

Dry age-related macular degeneration

  • Initially characterized by macular Drusens, which later progress to geographical atrophy
  • Treatment
    • Antioxidants like the AREDS2 supplement have proven effective.

Note: Exudates are usually present in a background of retinal vascular changes such as microaneurysms, dot and blot haemorrhages, whereas drusens usually do not have associated retinal vascular changes.

questions.text: Haab’s striae are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

Note: 

Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

 

Image: Haab's striae

Image (above): Buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma

Image (above): Vogt's striae.

questions.text: The last visual field to be affected in glaucoma is ____________
questions.solution:
The temporal visual field is the last field to be affected in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and, and finally the nasal fibers.

Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. The most likely diagnosis is ___________.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Elschnig’s pearls which are a type of after cataract—a delayed complication of cataract surgery.


Elschnig’s pearls are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

Other options:


Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome
Postoperative cystoid macular edema; delayed complication; clinically insignificant; resolves on its own

Option C: Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis
Caused when an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becomes trapped within the capsular bag; characterized by pain and redness.

Option D: UGH syndrome 
Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously; seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

questions.text: What type of presbyopic lens is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given lens in the image is a typical example of progressive lenses. Progressive lenses are identified as such due to the absence of the line of demarcation on the lens. They are gradually optimized for reading vision, distant vision, and for intermediate vision, such as computer work.

Executive bifocal type is preferred for pediatric aphakia/pseudophakia.

questions.text: Identify the test represented by the following image.
questions.solution:
The image above depicts lacrimal scintigraphy.

Tests for evaluation of watering eye include 

  • Regurgitation test
  • Syringing
  • Fluorescein dye disappearance test (FDDT)
  • Jones dye test
    • The primary test differentiates epiphora (overflow of tears) due to obstruction of the lacrimal passages or due to the primary hypersecretion of tears.
    • The secondary (irrigation) test identifies whether epiphora is due to a functional obstruction (lacrimal pump failure) or a physical obstruction (absolute/partial obstruction).
  • Dacryocystography
  • Dacryoscintigraphy

questions.text: Identify the refractive error in the image.
questions.solution: The above image represents the rays of light forming two focal points one before the retina and one on the retina. This type of astigmatism is called simple myopic astigmatism.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation. She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image is given below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
  1. It is usually associated with regular astigmatism
  2. Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool
  3. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice
  4. Vogt's striae and Rizzuti sign are both findings 
  5. The area of protrusion is mostly inferotemporal
questions.solution:
Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder.  It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and connective tissue disease.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection. 

Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady presents with eye pain, photophobia, and red-eye. The slit-lamp examination finding is shown below. On which layer of the cornea are these present?
questions.solution:
The clinical history along with the slit lamp finding of keratic precipitates suggests a diagnosis of acute anterior uveitis. Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits occurring at the back of the cornea (endothelium).

They are arranged in a triangular fashion, occupying the center and inferior parts of the cornea (Arlt's triangle).

questions.text: A UNICEF volunteer presented with a bilateral red eye of 2 days duration beginning on a return flight from Ghana. The patient reported that the same infection dramatically spread among all her family members within a day of her return. Initial examination revealed lid edema, serous discharge, and severe sub-conjunctival hemorrhage. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with bilateral red-eye and a rapid spread of infection to family members points towards a likely diagnosis of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Examination findings of lid edema, serous discharge, and subconjunctival hemorrhage further consolidate this diagnosis.

Causes:

  • Enterovirus 70 (most important)
  • Coxsackievirus 24
  • Echovirus 34
  • Adenovirus
  • Pneumococcus
  • Haemophilus

There is no treatment currently available. The infection generally resolves itself within a five to seven-day period. The use of steroids can actually cause a corneal microbial superinfection which then requires antimicrobial therapy to eliminate.

The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

Note: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis was first recognized as a clinical entity in Ghana in 1969 when a worldwide pandemic ensued due to the infection from enterovirus 70.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of squint seen in children?
questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint seen in children.

Most common type of squint overall: accommodative esotropia

Second most common overall: congenital/Infantile esotropia

Most common type of exotropia: primary exotropia

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. Which of the following pair of muscles are likely to be affected in this patient?

choices.text: Levator palpebrae superioris and superior oblique
Levator palpebrae superioris and Muller's muscle

questions.solution:
The patient has mild right eye ptosis. Injury or weakness of levator palpebrae superioris and Muller's muscle leads to ptosis.

Levator palpebrae superioris is the important upper eyelid retractor. Frontalis and Muller’s muscle assist in the elevation of the upper eyelid.

questions.text: Where does the crystalline lens derive its nutrition from?
questions.solution:
The crystalline lens derives its nutrition from the aqueous humor.

The lens is an avascular structure. It receives nutrition mostly from the aqueous humor and, to some extent, from the vitreous humor as well. Glucose is the main energy source.

Major intrinsic protein 26 (MIP 26)/Aquaporin 0 in the lens is responsible for maintaining transparency by transporting water and glycerol across the lens.

Anti-oxidant mechanisms in the lens

  • Reduced glutathione (most important)
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Catalase
  • Vitamins: Vit C , Vit E , carotenoids

questions.text: On ocular examination,  a patient known to have inborn errors of metabolism shows the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows Kayser–Fleisher ring, which is seen in Wilson’s disease.
  • Another finding in Wilson’s disease: Sunflower cataract

questions.text: Which among the following statements is not true about group discussion?

choices.text: Many different topics are spoken about in one discussion.
A group leader guides the conversation.
It can bring about change in attitude of the participants.
It usually consists of 6 to 12 people.

questions.solution:
A group discussion discusses one topic on its agenda.

Group discussion is an aggregation of people interacting in a face to face manner.

  • Exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influences a change in their attitudes.
  • It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation, giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves.
  • In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interruption of another.
  • Limitation – not everyone is open to speaking in public and possibility of diversion of topic of discussion is high when many people are involved.

questions.text: Current annual growth rate of a population can be calculated by:

choices.text: Crude birth rate – crude death rate
Crude birth rate + crude death rate

questions.solution:
Current annual growth rate = crude birth rate – crude death rate.

Annual growth rate= (birth rate- death rate)/10 : The denominator 10 is used because we calculate the annual growth rate every 10 years in the census. Therefore, for current annual growth rate, the denominator will not be used.

questions.text: Mixing biomedical waste with different constituents before disposal to reduce its toxicities is known as _______.
questions.solution:
Inertization is the process of mixing the biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity in the waste and to reduce the contamination of ground water.
It is most commonly used for incineration ash with high metal content

The typical composition of the mixture is

  • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% cement
  • 15% lime
  • Water

Other options:

  • Incineration is a waste management method that involves the controlled burning of waste materials at high temperatures. It is often used for the disposal of various types of waste, including biomedical waste. Incineration is effective in reducing the volume of waste and destroying potentially infectious or hazardous materials through the application of high heat.
  • Compacting is a waste management technique that involves reducing the volume of waste by compressing it. This is typically done using specialized machinery or compactors. Compacting can make waste easier to transport and store, but it does not inherently reduce the toxicity of the waste.

questions.text: Crippling fluorosis occurs at what levels of fluoride intake:
questions.solution:
Crippling fluorosis is seen at fluoride intake >10mg/L, which in this question is 11mg/L.

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L
  • Genu valgum: In people consuming jowar(sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.
  • Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation and filtration.

questions.text: A Ph.D. scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study for the association of H. pylori with IBD from the gastroenterology wards. Which of the following must she do?

choices.text: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitor
Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
Exclude all patients with diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.solution: Cohort studies progress from cause to effect. Thus, the patients with IBD must be excluded. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for identifying ‘at-risk’ infants in a child health clinic?
questions.solution:
Birth weight less than 2.5kg (and not 2.8kg) is a criterion for identifying at-risk infants. At a child health clinic, the criteria to identify at-risk infants include:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with PEM, diarrhea
  • Working mother or single parent

questions.text: Among the following options, disease elimination can be helped the most by ____.
questions.solution:
Disease elimination can be helped the most by herd immunity. 

When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease. Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization for diseases like polio, diphtheria, and measles, goes a long way in helping the elimination of disease. A large section of the population would be immune to disease through herd immunity. 

Option A: The purpose of isolation is to protect the community by preventing the transfer of infection from the reservoir to the possible susceptible hosts

Option B: Quarantine refers to restrictions on the healthy contacts of an infectious disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most heat-sensitive vaccine?
questions.solution:
Oral polio vaccine is the most heat-sensitive vaccine.

questions.text: What does number 2 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?

choices.text: Diagnosed hypertensive subjects not on treatment

questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves, which is observed in hypertension, and "number 2" denotes normotensive subjects.

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole Community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

questions.text: What is the largest fund for population and reproduction-related programs?
questions.solution:
United Nations Population Fund or formerly known as United Nations Fund for Population Activities(UNFPA), is the largest fund for sexual and reproductive health activities.

The goals of UNFPA are:  

  • To support reproductive health care for the women and the youth  
  • To help pregnant women, especially the ones who face maternal complications
  • Provide access for all to modern contraceptives.
  • Provide training for health workers to ensure childbirths are supervised by skilled attendants
  • Prevention of gender-based violence and female genital mutilation
  • Prevention of teen pregnancies and ending child marriage
  • Delivery of safe birth supplies, dignity kits, and other materials to survivors of conflict and natural disaster
  • Collection of data, census and analyze them for development and planning.  

The Resources and Funding are divided into core resources and non-core resources.

Core resources are used to effectively provide essential sexual and reproductive health services to those in need and in crisis.

Non-core resources include thematic funds such as UNFPA Supplies, the Maternal and New-born Health Thematic Fund, the Humanitarian Action Thematic Fund, Population Data Thematic Fund, and other funds which are goal-based. Some of the others include regional, issue-based or multi-country programs and initiatives.

questions.text: All the following are notifiable occupational diseases under the Factories act except ____________.
questions.solution: Bagassosis is not a notifiable disease.

questions.text: Project “Axshya” is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means ‘free from TB’ which is the ultimate goal of the project and the national TB programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by The International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services,
  • Community participation in TB care and control,
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

World Tuberculosis Day, observed on 24 March each year, is designed to build public awareness about the global epidemic of tuberculosis and efforts to eliminate the disease. The theme for 2019 is 'It's time'.

questions.text: In a community, there are usually 40-50 reported cases of dengue every week. This week, there were 48 reported cases. This is would classify as:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of endemic disease.

Endemic refers to the constant presence and /or usual prevalence of a disease or infectious agent in a population within a geographic area.

Epidemic refers to an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of disease above what is normally expected in that population in that area. 

Outbreak carries the same definition of an epidemic, but is often used for a more limited geographic area.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. Now she presents with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago. She should now be given?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The girl should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone

She presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and she has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

According to the recommendations of the CDC:

Vaccination History Clean Minor Wounds All other wounds
Unknown or fewer than 3 doses Tdap/Td Tdap/TD + TIG
3 or more doses Tdap/ Td Only if > 10 years Tdap/TD Only if > 5 years

Tdap - Tetanus, Diptheria, and Pertussis

Td - Tetanus and Diptheria

Tdap for children and Td for adults but Tdap is preferred to Td for adults who have never received Tdap.

 

Categories of Tetanus immunization:

  • Category A - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within past 5 years
  • Category B - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past > 5 years < 10 years.
  • Category C - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past >10 years
  • Category D - Not taken a complete course of TT/booster or immunity status not known.

 

Note:

WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria containing vaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between booster doses.

questions.text: Pre-exposure prophylaxis for rabies is given on _______
questions.solution: Pre-exposure prophylaxis is given for rabies on Days 0, 7, 21, or 28.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Random error is a type of error in epidemiological studies that is difficult to eliminate and it is different from bias. Random error is when a value of the sample measurement diverges - due to chance alone - from that of the true population value, whereas bias comes under the category of systematic errors.

Other options:

  • Recall or Memory Bias: This occurs when there is differential recall of exposure or outcome information between cases and controls, leading to an over- or underestimation of the true association.
  • Confounding: Confounding occurs when an extraneous variable is associated with both the exposure and the outcome and can distort the true relationship between them.
  • Selection Bias: Selection bias occurs when there is a systematic difference between the cases and controls in terms of how they are selected or recruited into the study, leading to a biased estimate of the association between exposure and outcome.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true for a screening test?

1) Done on apparently healthy

2) Applied to individuals

3) Time-consuming

4) Relatively inaccurate results

5) Based on one criterion/ cut off
questions.solution:
Screening tests are done on apparently healthy individuals, the results of the test are relatively inaccurate, the tests are based on one criterion.

The difference between screening and diagnostic tests is given below:

Screening test Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on patients with signs and symptoms

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients

Based on one criterion or cut-off point

Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings

Less accurate

More accurate

Less expensive

More expensive

Not a basis for treatment

Used as a basis for treatment

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint

Screening tests are recommended in the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis changes the disease course
  • In a disease with an asymptomatic stage
  • In a disease with a test for diagnosis and treatment
  • The natural history of the disease is well known

questions.text:
A group of demographers studied the changes in the birth and death rates of two countries, A and B from the year 2001 to 2011. The collected data is given below. In which stages of the demographic cycle are countries A and B in respectively?

Country A:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 38.3 38.3
Death rate 13.7 10.2

Country B:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 12.4 12.3
Death rate 6.7 6.6
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle. 

According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary stage of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is diagnosed with cholera. Which of the following drug would you prescribe to his family members to prevent the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera.

It should be given for:

  • Adults - a 3-day period in a twice-daily dose of 500mg
  • Children (4-13 years) - 125mg
  • Children (0-3 years) - 50mg

Alternatively, single oral dose of doxycycline may be used for chemoprophylaxis. The dose is 300 mg for adults and 6 mg/kg for children under 15 years.

Chemoprophylaxis is advised only for household contacts or a closed community in which cholera has occurred.
